0.78.text:
>> From the Library of
Congress in Washington, D.C.

20.36.text:
I'm Fenella France, Chief
of the Preservation Research

22.15.text:
and Testing Division, and
I'd like to welcome you today

24.57.text:
to a [inaudible] lecture on Medieval
Medicine for Modern Infections.

28.92.text:
Could Ancientbiotics
help in the fight

34.27.text:
I'd like to introduce
our speaker today,

36.48.text:
Dr. Erin Connelly who's the
[inaudible] fellow for data curation

40.62.text:
and medieval studies [inaudible]
Institute for manuscript studies

48.16.text:
She holds a Ph.D. in Medieval
English from the University

50.99.text:
of Nottingham and her doctoral
[inaudible] was a first edition

56.26.text:
of [inaudible] a significant
medieval medical text.

64.29.text: She also holds a BC in biology

66.44.text:
and worked briefly in
molecular oncology.

69.08.text:
She's part of the Ancientbiotics
team which explores the relevance

72.78.text:
of medieval medicines
for modern infections.

75.84.text:
I know you're going to find
this absolutely fascinating,

78.07.text: and I'm going to hand over to Erin.

85.43.text:
>> Erin Connelly: Thank you very
much to Fenella and to everyone here

90.01.text:
at the Library of Congress for
inviting me to speak today.

93.35.text:
I am very much looking forward to
sharing this research with you.

99.48.text:
So we have a few objectives
for today's talk.

104.60.text:
In summary, the Ancientbiotics
team tests the efficacy

109.72.text:
of medieval medicines
for modern infections.

113.96.text:
And I'm going to be talking
about a successful pilot study

119.48.text:
on a 1000-year-old recipe
known as Bald's Eyesalve,

124.28.text:
which turned out to be a potent
anti-staphylococcal agent.

129.14.text:
Its repeatedly killed Staph
aureus biofilms in vitro

134.24.text:
and it killed methicillin
resistant Staph aureus or MRSA

139.15.text: in a mouse chronic wound model.

141.58.text:
Now because this pilot
study occurred in 2015,

148.04.text: we'll also be talking about current

151.05.text:
and future research plans
of which there are many.

156.19.text:
Now, I'm going to be
presenting scientific evidence

161.61.text:
from the pilot study, but I speak
to you today as a medievalist

167.29.text:
and although this research
does hold implications

176.50.text:
It also raises very interesting
questions about the methodology

186.57.text:
And for a long time,
the middle ages,

192.25.text:
medieval medicine has been dismissed
as irrelvant, overly superstitious,

199.44.text:
a time of gathering
information solely

207.28.text:
We're all familiar with the term
dark ages, labeling the period

212.41.text:
as unenlightened by
science or reason.

218.45.text:
However, recent scholarship may
show that there is more methodology

225.90.text:
to the medicines of
medieval practitioners

230.41.text:
and further inquiry may show
that their medicines were more

236.85.text:
than just placebos
or palliative aids

240.60.text:
but actual antibiotics being
used long before the advent

249.60.text:
So as a medievalist, I
thought it best begin

255.62.text: with a story from medical history.

259.58.text:
What you see on your
screen is an excerpt

264.42.text:
from Thomas Gale's Certaie
Workes of Chirurgerie.

267.90.text:
Now, Thomas Gale was
a 16th century master

272.06.text:
of the London Barber Surgeon's
Guild, and he's connected

276.87.text:
with the [inaudible] of
one of the text studied

281.99.text:
Fenella mentioned it's known
as the lilly of medicines.

286.96.text: In the foleo preceding this except,

290.16.text:
Thomas Gale relates a personal case
study of a young boy with sore eyes.

297.07.text:
He says, "Every member of the guild
is working on treating this child.

304.06.text:
but it only brings the
child's condition to worse."

308.50.text:
Until Gale says, "We left the
child to the work of nature."

314.36.text:
However, the child's mother
found a recipe in an old book,

320.58.text:
brought this recipe to
Gale who distilled it,

322.96.text:
applied it to the child and as
you see underlined in the slide,

327.19.text:
he says, "Restored the child's
eyes to perfect health and sight."

333.14.text:
Now, although Gale's account
is several centuries old,

338.80.text:
it is analgous to our
current situation.

343.02.text:
At present, there's an
urgent need for novel routes

348.90.text:
to drug discovery due
to the emergence

351.47.text:
of antibiotic resistant bacteria
and the lack of new drugs currently

357.54.text:
in development to treat
antibiotic resistant infections.

362.86.text:
The World Health Organization
stated in September,

369.87.text:
2016 that antimicrobial resistance
is an increasingly serious threat

376.38.text:
to global public health
that requires action

380.20.text:
across all government
sectors and society.

384.20.text:
In 2017, the CDC related a case
study of a woman in Nevada who died

390.93.text: of an infection that was resistant

392.90.text:
to every known antimicrobial
in the United States.

397.50.text:
Current estimates say that
around 700,000 people a year

402.48.text:
around the world die of
antimicrobial resistant infections

408.59.text:
and if no action is
taken, that estimate jumps

416.67.text:
Now on your screen here
is a dramatic gesture

421.35.text:
by image comics funded
by the Welcome Trust

425.23.text:
to capture broad public attention
about this threat to health.

429.61.text: This is a comic book series

431.55.text:
that envisions a post
antibiotic dystopia actually

436.48.text: in a much nearer future than 2050.

438.82.text:
This one is set in 2036, in which
millions of people are dying

448.20.text:
Like Thomas Gale's remedy from an
old book, there are some historians

457.88.text:
and scientists who
believe that the answer

460.93.text:
to the antibiotic crisis may
be found in medical history

470.62.text:
So in response to this
pressing global threat,

475.18.text:
the Ancientbiotics team
was formed in 2014.

478.91.text:
It is a truly interdisciplinary
and international team.

486.27.text:
We are united by the
belief that novel routes

490.70.text:
to drug discovery are necessary
as well as the conviction

495.22.text:
that the past could
inform the future.

498.80.text:
So along those lines, I'm going
to present some of the evidence

504.75.text:
from the pilot study on an eye
remedy called Bald's Eyesalve,

510.44.text:
and the following slides represent
data taken from the original paper,

516.64.text: which was published in in bio.

518.53.text:
It's available online and represents
work done by [inaudible] Harrison,

539.69.text:
This is the recipe as it appears
in a book called Bald's Leechbook.

545.46.text:
1000-year-old remedy book
held by the British library.

549.76.text: Now it is written in old English.

556.41.text:
But in modern English, as translated
by Christina Lee, it reads something

563.24.text:
like make an eyesalve
against a wind.

567.68.text:
Take equal amounts of an
allium species and garlic.

573.54.text:
Pound them well together, take
equal amounts of wine and oxgall.

583.24.text: Put this in a brass vessel.

584.87.text:
Let the mixture stand for nine
nights in the brass vessel.

590.42.text:
Wring through a cloth
and clarify it well.

595.58.text:
Put in a horn and at night apply
it to the eye with a feather.

604.56.text:
Now, a wind in modern terms
could be translated as a sty

611.34.text:
which is an infection
of the eyelash follicle.

614.94.text:
And in modern terms,
the most common cause

618.22.text:
of infection is the gram-positive
bacterium Staphylococcus aureus,

624.99.text:
which also causes other severe
and persistent infections.

632.17.text: So what does the data show?

634.92.text:
This is what the eyesalve
looks like.

646.79.text:
in the recipe is a little
bit ambiguous, a leek version

651.70.text:
and an onion version of eyesalve
was made, and this is because leek

657.77.text:
and onion, they both contain
antimicrobial flavonoids,

661.58.text:
not found in garlic which is
already part of the recipe.

665.18.text:
And onion also contains
an antimicrobial peptide.

669.41.text:
So two versions of the
eyesalve were made.

672.04.text: One with leek, one with onion.

675.04.text:
Preparations of individual
ingredients, versions of the recipes

681.69.text:
with ingredients deleted and
then preparations of the recipe

686.34.text:
to be tested before and after this
nine day activation period were

693.06.text:
And it is noteworthy that after
these nine days the recipe

706.27.text:
Bald's eyesalve kills Staph
aureus in planktonic culture,

710.75.text:
and in synethetic wound
biofilm model.

714.75.text:
In figure A, a control of sterile
distilled water which is represented

721.28.text:
by the black line as
well as the two versions

724.62.text: of the recipe, onion and leek.

726.88.text:
Onion is represented
by the red line.

728.66.text:
And the leek is represented
by the blue line were added

733.23.text:
to Staph aureus growing
in synthetic wound fluid

738.75.text:
of the culture was taken
during 18 hours of incubation.

743.77.text:
You can very clearly see in this
image the difference in activity

747.60.text:
between the control
and the two eyesalves.

750.99.text:
In figure B, a control again
of sterile distilled water,

758.64.text:
the two variance of
eyesalve onion and leek

761.05.text:
and then each individual
ingredient on its own were added

766.15.text:
to Staph aureus growing in a
synthetic wound biofilm model.

773.64.text:
that are significantly
different from the control.

777.40.text:
And you'll note here
that on their own,

781.14.text:
each individual ingredient
had no significant effect

788.62.text:
However, the highlighted version
of the two full recipes did.

793.17.text:
And this is a key idea, this
combination of ingredients.

798.92.text:
This is where we seem to see this
potent anti-staphylococcal activity.

805.10.text:
So along those lines, the
activity of Bald's eyesalve

809.92.text:
against Staph aureus biofilms
requires several ingredients.

818.05.text:
Here, there are the two
versions of the eyesalve,

821.81.text: the full recipe, onion and leek.

823.94.text:
And then variance of the recipe
with ingredients deleted along

829.10.text:
with an assessment
of their full partial

835.96.text:
So here the gray bar is
showing the control again

841.20.text: The red bars are showing the full

843.38.text:
and reduced versions
for the onion eyesalve.

846.54.text:
The blue is showing full and reduced
versions for the leek eyesalve

851.40.text:
and the green is showing
a variant of the recipe

854.24.text: with both onion and leek deleted.

857.70.text:
So what to take away
from this image?

863.00.text:
Deleting wine and garlic
from both variance

867.38.text:
of the eyesalve totally eliminates
the bactericidal activity.

872.73.text:
So it would seem that
the combination of wine,

877.13.text:
garlic and allium species
are crucial

881.46.text:
for the full efficacy
of Bald's eyesalve.

885.04.text:
Also, when onion is used instead of
leek, oxgall seems to be necessary.

892.71.text: In both cases, brass is dispensable.

897.82.text:
So because of this
combination of ingredients,

902.97.text:
we also look to the nine
day activation period

910.16.text:
There might be some
methodology to it.

912.93.text:
Here, again a control of sterile
distilled water and the two variance

917.17.text:
of eyesalve were added
to Staph aureus growing

921.10.text:
in a wound biofilm model
immediately after preparation.

925.99.text:
And the bactericidal
activity was quantified.

931.29.text:
Those results are shown
by the shaded bars.

935.69.text:
The experiment was repeated after
the nine day activation period,

943.16.text:
and that activity is
shown by the open bars.

948.86.text:
You can clearly see the
difference in activity

953.50.text:
over this nine day waiting period
between the shaded and open bars

958.54.text: in both variance of the eyesalve.

961.70.text:
So what I just talked about is in
vitro results against Staph aureus.

970.75.text:
Because it performed so well
in these tests, it was decided

976.63.text:
that it should be tested in vivo
against a resistant pathogen.

984.51.text:
Tissue from wound samples of mice
infected with MRSA were submerged

991.51.text: in a control of sterile saline,

995.51.text:
vancomycin which is a
clinical last line antibiotic

1000.03.text:
and then the two variance
of the eyesalve.

1009.29.text:
which are significantly
different from the control.

1012.99.text:
You will note that the last line
antibiotic vancomycin produced no

1023.67.text: However, both of the eyesalves did.

1027.20.text:
So it would seem that Bald's
eyesalve shows potential

1035.68.text:
as an anti-staphylococcal agent
not only in vitro but in vivo

1045.32.text:
So what about against
nonbacterial parasites?

1051.18.text:
So Leishmaniasis for those who
might not be familiar with it,

1058.20.text:
It is caused by the bite
of female sand flies.

1062.57.text:
It has a major problem in
warm parts of the world,

1067.38.text:
and it's becoming an
increasing problem

1070.95.text:
with large scale displacement
of humans

1075.33.text: and people living in refugee camps.

1078.53.text:
And what it does is it causes
very unpleasant lesions

1085.52.text:
which are then susceptible to
infection by secondary bodies

1090.74.text: like Staph aureus and other species.

1093.98.text:
So this work is -- has
been done by Lee Haines

1097.90.text:
of the Liverpool School
of Tropical Medicine.

1100.74.text:
She's pictured here in the slide
taking a swab from a patient,

1105.88.text:
and the other image that you see
is a [inaudible] stained slide

1114.76.text: The gray area are red blood cells.

1118.60.text: The purple area is the macrophage.

1121.65.text:
The large dark purple area
is the nucleus and then

1125.30.text:
if you look closely you
can see dark purple specks.

1132.45.text:
and what they do is they
evade human immunity by hiding

1140.28.text:
They rupture the cell and then
invade other macrophage cells.

1146.02.text:
Oh, word of warning
before the next slide.

1151.63.text:
I know we are not all
scientists here.

1154.35.text:
So I'm about to show a somewhat
graphic image of a patient

1158.48.text:
with pretty severely infected
Leishmaniasis lesions.

1162.60.text:
So if you find that disturbing,
perhaps proceed with caution.

1169.97.text:
So you can see the immense
pain and suffering that results

1177.59.text:
from these lesions,
particularly when Staph aureus

1181.01.text:
or another bacteria
begins an infection.

1184.65.text:
And especially for people
who have been displaced,

1190.41.text:
without adequate access
to medical care.

1194.31.text:
And once these lesions heal,
they often cause scarring,

1198.93.text:
pretty significant
scarring on the face,

1202.27.text: and that can lead to social stigma.

1205.36.text:
It can lead to bullying and
depression, a loss of education

1209.58.text:
if children then don't want to
go to school and in some parts

1213.22.text: of the world for young girls,

1215.45.text:
it can lead to a loss
of marriage prospects.

1219.11.text:
So if you contract this and
you live in a part of the world

1222.94.text:
with stable access to medical
care, you could receive treatment

1231.42.text:
But typically the drug most usually
used is called pentastem [ph],

1237.47.text:
and this is injected either
intramuscularly or intralesionally.

1243.58.text:
And depending on the
type of species,

1251.65.text:
the treatment can be quite
painful, quite long up to 18 months

1258.31.text:
And you can imagine this is quite a
disheartening prospect for patients.

1264.45.text:
Some people will refuse
the injections and try

1267.57.text:
and treat it themselves by
burning the lesions with cigarettes

1271.63.text:
or with fire, trying
to cut the lesion,

1274.84.text:
which clearly is not going
to help the situation.

1278.43.text:
So what does this have
to do with eyesalve?

1286.99.text:
In the assay shown here, live
parasites were exposed to dilutions

1296.10.text: of both versions of the eyesalve.

1298.57.text:
Both onion and leek
over a two day period.

1302.79.text:
After the two day period,
a dye was added in order

1307.87.text:
to measure metabolic
activity to measure

1311.97.text: if the parasites are alive or dead.

1315.53.text:
When parasites are alive,
the dye turns bright pink.

1321.38.text:
When parasites are dead,
the dye stays dark blue.

1326.06.text:
And you can see where
it says onion variant

1328.84.text:
and leek variant the
dye is dark blue.

1336.74.text:
Now, this is quite
an exciting result

1340.75.text: but it's also a preliminary result.

1343.91.text:
Right now the eyesalve is being
tested on human macrophage cells

1349.59.text:
in order to ascertain its
effects on human cells.

1354.76.text:
So it has to be determined that the
eyesalve is harmless to human cells

1363.45.text:
but maintains its toxicity against
the parasites living within them.

1370.05.text:
To summarize this evidence, but I
went through a little bit quickly,

1377.04.text:
all of the ingredients are necessary
for the eyesalve to work except

1386.18.text:
Also necessary is this
nine day activation period.

1390.85.text:
This idea of a combination
of ingredients

1394.45.text:
in premodern medicine
is quite a key idea.

1402.33.text:
It could be that the
antimicrobial activity

1406.81.text:
of the individual ingredients
on their own is combining

1411.79.text:
to make the eyesalve greater
than some of its parts.

1416.35.text:
It could be that bacteria
is being attacked

1422.94.text:
It also could be that this nine day
activation period perhaps a novel

1428.54.text:
compound is being formed
over this time.

1432.01.text:
These are questions to be
answered by future research

1436.06.text: and that is where it is heading.

1441.56.text:
The recipe is highly
reproducible, which is significant.

1446.54.text:
As of right now, six people
have made a couple dozen batches

1453.06.text:
of the eyesalve using fresh
ingredients each time and all

1458.27.text:
of them work equally well
against Staph aureus.

1462.39.text:
As I alluded to, current tests
are being done on Bald's eyesalve

1469.62.text:
for its effects on human
cells, and that will determine

1476.26.text:
Also, an analysis of how it's
working, why is it effective?

1484.12.text:
Is there a novel compound
being formed?

1489.44.text: And switching gears a little bit,

1495.50.text:
you'll recall from the beginning
I related story of Thomas Gale

1503.42.text:
So this is the text that I
produced the first edition

1507.09.text:
of for my doctoral work,
and it contains a wealth

1512.09.text:
of pharmaceutical information
so from that text,

1516.33.text:
we're doing something
a little bit different.

1518.55.text:
There is a chapter
on weakness of sight,

1523.61.text:
and within that chapter there
are different remedies for loss

1528.28.text:
of eyesight, debilitating vision,
problems related to old age.

1535.10.text:
And so there's a recipe
that in translation

1538.11.text:
from the middle English it says God
has not given us a better recipe

1544.56.text:
It makes even old men to read

1549.41.text: And so that is quite the promise.

And so we decided to test that

That is an ongoing test

by Lisa Charkarubarti [assumed

of Nottingham but we do hope to have

1570.77.text:
Another interesting ingredient from

Now, this may be an unfamiliar herb

1585.28.text:
in medical history being used
by Greek authorities all the way

1592.33.text:
up to the present day even

1596.60.text:
One scholar has termed it nature's

1601.26.text:
at wound healing, insect stings
and also infection prevention,

1607.76.text:
which is also part of

So right now we're -- this

but we hope to look at Plantago
major, Plantago [inaudible]

for effects in wound healing

Also, you'll see on her a

But that one because of this

1664.71.text:
and the anecdotal evidence I

We're also going to be testing

And maybe develop something

So of all of these ongoing

1681.90.text:
for the remainder of our

1686.21.text:
in on a recipe database and a

on data mining, the

Just a little bit more
about this text.

1704.38.text:
It is the only extant middle

1710.47.text:

which was originally written

1719.12.text:
Then the middle English translation

in the late -- very
late 17th century.

So you can see from the date span

1738.34.text:
through the medieval period
through the Renaissance

1751.82.text:
That was probably the most

What I've done, the lyly

to particular ingredients, 360 very

And I put these into a database

All of these recipes that

Bald's eyesalve, the remedy

and picking method

So that is what we're

we're looking to have some

And not only would such a

which has implications for new drug
